There we are Aunt May, I think we can start our interview now.
And the first thing I wanted to ask you about is to go over what you've told me other times
about the Welch people coming up to St. John River Valley and settling finally at Cardigan and up in York County.
Well, I contend you don't need to take that.
No, that's okay.
I contend you, my folks belong to, came from Cardigan in Wales.
And they came to St. John of course by boat.
When they got here, they went by boat as far as Sheffield.
When they got out as far as Sheffield, they disembarked, but the boat didn't go any farther, I don't know.
They started to walk to Fredericton, and it was late in the fall, and the only one who could talk to him was the school teacher.
Yes, the other spoke only Welsh.
Only Welsh, and so when the folks from Fredericton heard they were on their way,
some of them came down to meet them to see what their plans were, and all they could say to them was teacher, school teacher.
So he went, he hunted the school teacher up, and the school teacher told them that they were headed for Cardigan in York County.
Now Cardigan was nothing but woods and rocks.
I wonder if they knew that when they came out.
No, they had, if they did, there must be a lot of rocks in Wales, because they picked out the rockies far by the country.
It could be they were deceived, you know, like the Danish people who went up to New Denmark.
Oh yes, I would be in surprise, yes.
No one told them it was all virgin forest, and they'd have to clear up there.
Well anyway, it was so late in the fall, and there wasn't a house for them up there, that the Fredericton people wouldn't let them go at all.
They would let them even think of going up there at that time of the year.
So they took them in, some of them took them into their homes, some of them, and the men folks got work.
There was a man by the name of Saunders who started a little store, and that store, Saunders' ran for years and years.
When I was a young girl, they were still there.
And some of them moved on up and eventually to Cardigan.
Well the men folks went up in the spring, and the women still stayed in Fredericton.
The men went up and they cut down trees, and they started and built a few log houses, and the women folks went up.
And they cleared a few bits of land and put a little crop in, and strived it out, I'd say.
Because there was no roadway except a dog path through the woods, and there they were.
Do you have any idea roughly what year this was when they arrived?
No, I couldn't tell you the year, but I think you could find that out at the Orson Briggs Museum.
Now it was way back in the form of when my grandmother was there, I think she was born here.
There'd be land office records too of the Grants.
My father's name was Evans, John I think, John Evans.
And what our mother's name was I don't know.
Except that you said they didn't pronounce it that way.
No, they called it Evans. They don't call it Evans, they called it Levens.
And in my youth they always called it Evans.
And I was, let me sit down over here.
Yes, perhaps I will.
My cousins, Evans' cousins were called Evans.
But when I named my son Evan, well, I don't know why Evan he is.
So anyway, my grandfather, his wife's name was Susan.
And he cut out a piece of land, cleared a piece of land and put up a house.
And they used to go to church in their bare feet.
Until they came to a certain rock below the greenhouse.
Of course one of the first things they did was put up a meeting house.
And when they came to that rock they carried their shoes.
They put their shoes on there, went barefoot, saved the shoes.
And then they took them off and they went back to the rock and walked home with their bare feet.
What denomination would they have been?
Well, it was Methodist. Methodist as it was years ago.
There wasn't a Methodist church there because there still is a Methodist church there but they don't use it.
Methodists I guess were or became the predominant denomination in Wales, didn't they?
They used to have sing songs and use a tuning fork.

Yes, Joneses up in that section.

Oh yes, no doubt at all.
Anyway these people lived and managed to live, they used to have to go to Fredericton on foot.
And carry their supplies back on their backs.
The women would take a basket of eggs and butter and walk 17 miles to Fredericton and cart home whatever they could get for their eggs and their butter.
They used to do the same with New Merrill and the East North.
Yeah.
And one woman walked clear to Fredericton and back and two miles from home she had to go into her neighbor's to have a new baby.
Two days later her husband came with an ox cart and took her home.
And one day when my grandfather was out, her great grandfather, was out in the woods, a tree fell on him and killed him.
And my grandmother said they were so poor that they sometimes had to pull up the potatoes they planted to eat.
They wouldn't have anything else they did, for they never had a chance to sprout.
They'd have to dig them up and eat them.
